steps.title: Peel and chop the guavas.
steps.content: Peel and chop the guavas. Wash several red or pink guavas. Use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin. While you can leave the peel on, it will make the juice thicker and grittier. Chop the guavas into chunks. You should end up with 1 cup (165 g). [1] X Research source Use guavas that are soft and free of spots or blemishes.

steps.title: Measure the ingredients into a blender.
steps.content: Measure the ingredients into a blender. Put the chopped guava into a blender or food processor. Add 1 teaspoon (4 g) of sugar and 1/2 cup (120 ml) of cold water. Put the lid on the blender or processor. [2] X Research source You could substitute your favorite low-calorie or natural sweetener for the sugar.

steps.title: Blend the guava mixture.
steps.content: Blend the guava mixture. Blitz the guava mixture just until the guava is smooth and mixed with the water. Avoid blending the mixture for too long or the seeds will become finely ground. This will make it difficult to strain them out and your guava juice will be gritty. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Strain the guava juice.
steps.content: Strain the guava juice. Set a fine mesh strainer over a bowl. For even smoother juice, line the strainer with cheesecloth. Scoop the guava mixture into the strainer and use a spoon to gently push the mixture through it. [4] X Research source You can discard the tiny, hard seeds that are left in the strainer.

steps.title: Add ice cubes and serve the guava juice.
steps.content: Add ice cubes and serve the guava juice. Place several ice cubes into 2 small serving glasses. Pour the strained guava juice into the glasses and serve it immediately. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Wash, peel, and chop the guavas.
steps.content: Wash, peel, and chop the guavas. Wash several soft, red or pink guavas. Use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin. While you can leave the peel on, it will make the juice thicker and grittier. Use a sharp knife to carefully chop the guavas so you get 3 cups (495 g).

steps.title: Blend and strain the guava.
steps.content: Blend and strain the guava. Put the chopped guavas into a blender or food processor. Blitz the guavas until they're smooth and pulpy. Set a fine mesh strainer over a bowl and transfer the guava mixture into it. Stir the mixture so it passes through the strainer. You can discard the seeds that are left in the strainer.

steps.title: Shake the pulp with the seasonings.
steps.content: Shake the pulp with the seasonings. Transfer the strained guava juice to a cocktail shaker. Add 1/4 teaspoon of ground ginger, 3 tablespoons (37.5 g) of sugar, 1/4 teaspoon of red chili powder, 1/4 teaspoon of lime juice, and 1/4 teaspoon of fresh mint. Put the lid on the shaker and shake it for 10 to 20 seconds. This will combine the pulp with the seasonings. If you don't have a cocktail shaker, you could just whisk the ingredients together in a bowl or measuring jug.

steps.title: Stir in water and serve the drinks over ice.
steps.content: Stir in water and serve the drinks over ice. Put a handful of ice cubes into 2 serving glasses. Pour half of the guava mixture into each glass. Pour 1 cup (240 ml) of cold, filtered water into each glass. Stir the drinks so the guava and water combine. Serve the drinks right away. If you like thicker guava juice, just use less filtered water.

steps.title: Wash and chop the guavas.
steps.content: Wash and chop the guavas. Wash 2 green guavas. Use a sharp knife to carefully chop the guavas into small cubes. Put the cubed guavas into a blender or food processor. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Blend the guavas with water.
steps.content: Blend the guavas with water. Pour 1/2 cup (120 ml) of water into the blender with the guavas. Blend the guava mixture just until the it's smooth. If you blend it too long, the seeds will become finely ground. This will make it difficult to strain them out and your guava juice will be gritty. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Strain and thin the guava puree.
steps.content: Strain and thin the guava puree. Set a fine mesh strainer over a bowl and scoop the guava mixture into it. Stir the mixture so it passes through the strainer. Discard the seeds left in the strainer and pour water into the strained guava puree according to your taste. [8] X Research source For example, if you like thick guava juice, you may only want to add a little more water. If you prefer a thinner guava juice, try adding another cup or 2 (240 to 480 ml) of water to the guava.

steps.title: Stir in lime, honey, and salt.
steps.content: Stir in lime, honey, and salt. Zest a little bit of fresh lime zest into the strained guava juice. Squeeze the lime and add all of the juice to the juice along with 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of honey and 1 pinch of salt. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Taste and serve the guava lime juice.
steps.content: Taste and serve the guava lime juice. Taste the guava juice and add sugar according to your taste. Divide the juice between four serving glasses and serve them immediately. [10] X Research source For a colder drink, add a few ice cubes to each glass just before you serve the drinks.
